Award.AwardTitle: Origins of Unique Optical Properties in Intermediate Band Nanocrystals
Award.AbstractNarration: PART 1: NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY<br/>When a metal is shrunk down to nanometer sizes, it can obtain new optical absorption features that donâ€™t exist in bigger, bulk materials. These new features, called plasmons, change the color of the metal, so that the commonly expected color becomes something different, like nanoscale gold colloids appearing red. Interestingly, there are some non-metals (semiconductors) that show this same effect at the nanoscale, but the origin and size-dependence of these effects is not well-understood. This project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, employs state-of-the-art x-ray characterization methods to elucidate unanswered structure-property questions of semiconducting nanocrystals. This project is examining several hypotheses to understand the nature of the semiconductor plasmons, including how excited electronic charges move in the materials and how these are affected by nano-sizing. To accomplish the goals, the PI is synthesizing nanocrystals, and characterizing them with methods including x-ray resonant inelastic x-ray scattering (RIXS) measurements through the quantum confinement size regime. The products of this work will benefit society because these nanocrystals have the potential for photovoltaic applications or they could lead to others such as photothermal therapy of tumor cell annihilation upon laser irradiation. These nanocrystals could also lead to high-frequency, all-optical modulation and switching of light. The accompanying outreach programs invigorate the public excitement about interesting Materials Chemistry through Lending Library demonstration kits on plasmonics. Furthermore, the PI mentors students of color through a program at Cornell.<br/><br/><br/>PART 2: TECHNICAL SUMMARY<br/>Certain metal chalcogenide nanocrystals have the ability to sustain absorption features that resemble localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPRs) typically seen in metal nanocrystals. The electronic origin of these features in these materials, however, is not completely understood. One theory is that interband electronic transitions lead to the features. This project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, employs state-of-the-art x-ray characterization methods to determine the influence of quantum confinement on the electronic bands and optical absorption profile of semiconducting nanocrystals. The central hypotheses are that transitions between bands control the absorption features and can be affected by quantum confinement. To test these hypotheses, this project is using synchrotron x-ray spectroscopy, including hard x-ray resonant inelastic x-ray scattering (RIXS) measurements and analysis, of nanocrystal semiconductors through the quantum confinement range. The team is synthesizing a size series of monodisperse nanocrystals, characterizing them with x-ray spectroscopy and optical absorption, and correlating the information with electronic structure models, to elucidate fundamental structure-property relationships. The products of this work will benefit society because these nanocrystals have the potential for photovoltaic applications or they could lead to others such as photothermal therapy of tumor cell annihilation upon laser irradiation. These nanocrystals could lead to high-frequency, all-optical modulation and switching of light. The accompanying outreach programs invigorate the public excitement about interesting Materials Chemistry through Lending Library demonstration kits on plasmonics. Furthermore, the PI mentors students of color through a program at Cornell.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry (SSMC) program supported work by Professor Richard Robinson at Cornell University. Professor Robinson was endowed to elucidate fundamental structure-property relationships in intermediate band nanocrystals (NCs). Intermediate band (IB) semiconductors possess a middle band of accessible states, located between the valence band (VB) and conduction band (CB). Bulk IB materials were previously studied for their possibility of up-conversion as photovoltaics, but recently, reports of IB NCs have illuminated exciting new properties. The work effort in this grant centered on determining the influence of quantum confinement on the electronic bands and optical absorption profile. This work investigated several outstanding questions concerning NCs of IB materials by developing synthetic methods to form monodisperse ternary copper sulfides and characterize their properties with spectroscopic experiments, including x-ray spectroscopy, and model the structure, including the electronic bands and electronic transitions.

 

The key intellectual merit outcomes of this work were to synthesize monodisperse NCs of ternary copper sulfides and model their band structure to understand how and if their absorption peak depended on the size and presence of the IB. The team was able to leverage a novel sulfur source: penicillamine. Penicillamine is an α-amino acid, with the structure of valine substituted at the beta position with a sulfanyl group. Its use as a sulfur source opens up new avenues for inexpensive precursors based on existing amino acids. The other novelty of the synthesis is that harnessing the "heat-up" method. The head-up method—which combines all ingredients at low temperatures then ramps up in temperature—is directly scalable to larger production since there is no reliance on injection speed and post-injection mixing. The characterization studies produced a number of outcomes, including determining that (1) CuFeS2 has a mixed cation oxidation state. As opposed to the pure Cu1+/Fe3+ predicted by DFT studies, a mixed oxidation state of Cu1+/Cu2+ and Fe2+/Fe3+ is observed. (2) the incorporation of Fe2+ in the nanocrystal is the origin for the optical resonance behavior. A critical Fe2+ cation molar percentage of 3.5% is required for the plasmon-like absorption. Additionally, this project modeled the band structure to understand the size-confinement effects in the optical properties of CuFeS2. Several outcomes for this portion of the project were (3) to show a quantum confinement effect in a tri-band system causes the valence band (VB) to intermediate band (IB), and the IB to conduction band (CB) gaps to expand as the particle size decreases. And (4) finding that the visible region absorption band in CuFeS2 nanocrystals is caused by the collective electronic transitions between valence and intermediate band.

 

The Broader Impact outcomes of this work was to establish an understanding of intermediate band nanocrystals that could lead to novel nanophotonics applications, such as THz all-optical modulation and switching of light and photothermal therapy of tumor cell annihilation. The PI introduced an amino acid as a new inexpensive precursor for nanocrystal synthesis. The PI’s Broader Impacts outcomes also integrated several educational and outreach initiatives. Briefly, the PI’s local and regional outreach efforts include mentoring graduate students, such as by serving as a Sloan Faculty Fellow at Cornell University that mentors diversity graduate students in engineering, and incorporating undergraduates into his research activities. The PI gave translational science talks to workshops for students of Historically Black Colleges and Universities, research experience for undergraduate participants, and diversity and women in engineering programs.
